As we all know America has incurred another great tragedy today, the loss of six Americans on Columbia. 
 
 While this is a horrible loss, no one should be calling for an end to our space program. The space program is something of national pride, but the research conducted is very important, and many things done are vital to many people. 
 
 NASA should begin working on a new space vehicle and take advantage of new technology. Remember, these shuttles are 23 years old. While we have now lost $4.2 billion in shuttle accidents, I think what we have done is well worth that cost. There is risk and any type of flight, and the men and women who man those flights know the danger and they know the odds. They are brave people. 
 
 Everyone should pray for those astronauts and their families today or tonight, and I hope they were Christians and that they are now with God.

oh yeah, we have gotten so much out of our space program. lets see...velcro? thats about it. and that was invented decades ago. we've had a space program for almost half a century and we have yet to land on mars. in fact, we've done nothing productive since landing on the moon in 1969. seriously folks, lets get our priorities straight.

You make it seem as if landing on Mars is easy. 
 
 What about the the medical research we've done? All our experiments? We've learned a lot and some medcines can only be manufactured in space... it's worth it.
list a few examples. if you list enough, then you might just convince me:)

Oh gosh... I don't even know much about what they do. But it's not all at taxpayer expense. Companies bid for experiments. 
 
 I know we've done a lot with medicines being manufactured in low gravity. We've also discovered that we can produce stronger materials in space because of low gravity. We can also take satellites up on shuttle missions. I don't know anything really specific, but good things do and will come out of it. 
 
 Eventually we can go to Mars and setup mineral or ice mining operations... more fresh water and more resources for our planet. 
 
 But the national pride alone is well worth the cost. We are one of two nations that can send people into space.

spending billions of dollars on "national pride"? not all of us are crazy nationalists like yourself broker. if you're willing to spend billions and billions and billions of dollars just so our country can brag, then that is fine. but you are in the minority on this one.

Fine by me. 
 
 What's done up there is well worth the cost too.
the cost of your silly nationalism is at the expense of this nation's poor

During the Columbia mission they did 90 experiments. I would say the space program is well worth it. 
 
 I'm not a crazy nationalist, either. Had the space program not been worth its weight it would have already been discontinued.
Remember that NASA is not just about the space program.

"As we all know America has incurred another great tragedy today, the loss of six Americans on Columbia" - Broker
 
 And I suppose the Israeli and the Indian don't count. I guess this is nit-picking and I'm sorry, but it makes me sick to see the division, disunity and war that stupid imaginary lines create. Who cares if they're American??? I say that we as HUMANS mourn the death of 7 PEOPLE, not Americans.
 
 I realize that this was probably an accident Broker but I can't believe no one said anything.

Well, I only mentioned America so I just counted Americans. The woman from India was an American citizen. 
 
 Six Americans and one Israeli. There :)

Originally posted by fallingupwards 
 list a few examples. if you list enough, then you might just convince me:) 
 
 
 1) Mini computers
 
 2) Weather prediction
 
 3) Solid state electronics
 
 4) World wide satelite communications
 
 5) Martime navigation charts
 
 6) Photo reconissance.
 
 7) Mineral exploration
 
 8) Oil exploration
 
 9) Wildlife management
 
 10) Food processing
 
 11) Solar photovoltiacs
 
 12) Fuel cells
 
 13) Pharmacuticals
 
 14) Espionage. Optical and electronic
 
 15) Combustion technology
 
 16) Agriculture management
 
 17) New alloys, plastics, and ceramics.
 
 18) GPS
 
 19) Ultra sensitive RF communications
 
 20) Digital Signal Processing
 
 21) Should I go on?
is that worth trillions of dollars?

Just the first 2 would have been worth it:
 
 1) Mini computers
 The mini general purpose computer produced high wage employment for thousands and thousand world wide and high tech fortunes from Intel to Bill Gates. They are in your car controlling fuel efficiency. They are on your desktop. They are in your microwave. They are: what are they not doing?
 
 2) Weather prediction
 Saved millions of lives world wide by being able to give advance warning to distaster. Prevented trillions of dollars of damage to martime shipping. Allowed farmers world wide protection for crops from weather damage. Allowed military operations to attack under best possible conidtions. Saftey for commercial airline travel world wide. Water management in desert climates.

As much as I hate big government. NASA has made profound world wide changes with spin off technology without any political or social agenda.
 
 NASA does have a political agenda for the promotion of everything American. But the production of mini computers and weather prediction as a spin off technology was not.

I think space travel is neat and all, and i admit many good things has come from space exploration. but i feel that the space program should be put on hold, at least for a while, especially since it looks like we will be going to war. it seems that there are no real experiments that need to be conducted in outerspace. i feel that the majority of the space programs, including the space station, is a waste of money. nothing new has been found, the Sojourne that went to mars was incredibaly cool, but how long did it last before it quit responding, and how much did it cost?

They were working on cancer medicines on the Columbia mission. I guess that's not important. 
 
 The Mars program is based now on faster, smaller, cheaper. That doesn't cost too much. 
 
 SO the advances in medicine, metals and polymers, and in technology were just a waste of money? 
 
 I read that they did 90 experiments on Columbia on that mission. What can they do with a permanent research lab? I bet we'll find that cure for cancer or that AIDS vaccine one day, and space may be where we find it.
Sojourner lasted many months more than it was supposed to... I think it was a six month lifespan? That's just an attempt to recall, so it may be way off.
why were they working on cancer research in space? that makes no sense. why would going into outerspace reveil a cure for any diseases.

because if they do some experiment in space, people like broker can brag about how great nasa is and how it needs more funding. the fact is, we can do the same research here on earth and it would be a lot less costly.

You obviously don't know what you're talking about. It's kind of hard to produce low gravity on Earth...the only way we can do is on a plane for around a minute. Gravity is very restricting. An absense of gravity... insert complicated chemcial reasoning here. 
 
 We would not be conducting research in space that we could on Earth. That would make no sense on Congress would starve the space program.
Also crystals are easier to grow in space. That's a big thing too.
so ill ask again, why do you need to do research in space for something here on earth?

You wouldn't research it in space and produce it on Earth... it would be produced in space, which actually would not be hard with the right equipment. I believe there were cures to some rare diseases developed in low gravity...seems like I read that somewhere. Anyone who can confirm or deny, please do. 
 
 Space is the future. This planet cannot contain us forever. We must move outward. We are depleting our resources and continuing to expand the human population... we can't go on forever. What we learn now will prove important in the future, and that future is soon. 
 
 And the reason we made it to the moon so fast was because we had an unlimited budget to beat Russia in its space program. That's the reason why we aren't on Mars. There was a plan to go in...1987? It would have cost 500 billion, so it went away.

There is one reason to do research in space, gravity. Sounds kindda stupid.
 
 Lots of natural behavior are affected by gravity: plasmas, liquid chemical reactions organic and inorganic, gas behavior, combustion, crystal growth, etc.
 
 Gravity makes the behavior more complicated. You really don't understand natural behavior unless you understand it under it's most simple conditions.
That counts as my "insert more complicated reasoning"

fallingupwards, i dont think that you know enough about nasa to critisize it
 
 yes it is expensive, and all you know is that we are sending people in space just to say we can
 
 you might not realize that many of the things you take for granted everyday were the result of nasa research
You already saw a list of stuff NASA has developed or were developed as a result or for NASA...
and i already told you, the things on that list are not worth the trillions of dollars we've spent on the nasa program

NASA had unlimited spending as a result of your friend Kennedy pushing us to land a man on the moon. I would say most expense was incurred then, not when we set NASA on a small budget. Smaller computers alone are worth it.
sounds like you want us to live in the dark ages so we can spend more money on bums and homeless people
yep, that is exactly what i want. how did you guess???

Going to say anything about my post? 
 
 You get mad at me when I skip your points, but everytime I make one you don't bother to reply...
i've already told you what i think. i'm not going to repeat the same thing over and over again. give me something new to debate about, and i'll do it.

NASA just does not do research into space flight. They do research into making comercial aircraft more fuel efficient, making cars more crash worthy, electronics more cheaper and durrable, human studies into behavior and leadership, medical research into aging and healthy senior citizens.
 
 NASA is a fund multiplier. The funds that go into NASA get multiplied when they spin off new technologies and developments. Think of small our enconomy would be if NASA never invented the mini-general-purpose-computer for the moon landing.
 
 NASA is worth it.

Originally posted by fallingupwards 
 because if they do some experiment in space, people like broker can brag about how great nasa is and how it needs more funding. the fact is, we can do the same research here on earth and it would be a lot less costly. 
 
 
 I'll use one example, plasma research. 
 
 Plasma research can be done on the Earth, but gravity makes plasma containment impossible because of instabilities. You can not begin to understand plasma behavior unless you get understand it under it's most simple condition.
 
 The day you can contain a stable plasma on Earth, is the day you can start generating unlimited nuclear power from sea water with no radiation!
 
 That is reason enough to go into space for research.
But we can't work on technology for the greater good! We need to spend our money on poor people who probably make around 5% of the changes in the US!

poor people are human beings too broker, believe it or not. and maybe they would be able to make a better contribution to society if they did not have to live in poverty. but lets not get off subject. i know a lot of people get mad when we do.
 
 you guys gave me a lot of good reasons for why the space program should exist. congrats, you've changed my mind...to a certain extent. if space exploration really does that much good for society then we should continue it. maybe it wouldnt hurt to cut back on some of the funding and use that to solve problems here at home. but at the same time, it looks to me that the space program can do a lot of good. 
 
 see, i'm not so close-minded. i consider other peoples opinions and when they seem to make sense, i change my mind.

When the space shuttle Discovery blasts off to the International Space Station (ISS) later today (launch scheduled Friday August 10, 2001 - 5.39 pm EDT), it will be taking with it a frozen clump of ovarian cancer cells. On the station, mission specialists will thaw them and grow them into a three-dimensional cluster that resembles the type of tumour one sees in the body, rather than into the abnormal shape on the flat bottom of a laboratory culture dish.
 
 The researchers from the University of South Florida College of Medicine and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) hope their culture will provide a biologically more accurate model for studies of ovarian cancer development and its responsiveness to chemotherapy and antihormonal agents.
 
 Such a three dimensional cluster can only be grown when the cells are in free fall and so subjected to a lower apparent gravitational pull (microgravity) than when sitting in a dish on Earth. Kevin Fong, lecturer in space medicine and physiology at University College London says this in vitro model could be revolutionary. 
 emoticon_cool

There's why we're doing cancer research in space, Falling. ;) 
 
 I never said poor people weren't people. I just don't think we should change this country so much to cater to those people. If the majority of the population was poor, yes, but it is not. 
 
 Space is our future, is it not? How long can we stay here? We are delpleting our resources and the population is exploding. That 15 billion is being spent well...you could go through other programs and find double or triple that amount not being spent well. I have no problem with helping people out of poverty. I do have a problem with unchecked spending on them and focusing on supporting them instead of getting them out of poverty.
I wouldn't mind giving my money to research something that might save someone's life.

 you guys gave me a lot of good reasons for why the space program should exist. congrats, you've changed my mind...to a certain extent. if space exploration really does that much good for society then we should continue it. maybe it wouldnt hurt to cut back on some of the funding and use that to solve problems here at home. but at the same time, it looks to me that the space program can do a lot of good. 
 
 see, i'm not so close-minded. i consider other peoples opinions and when they seem to make sense, i change my mind.

"If the majority of the population was poor, yes, but it is not"
 
 The majority of the world population is incredibly poor.
I was talking about our people, not the world's people.

That's not what he was saying and you know it!
